I mean, fortunately, I'm not a claustrophobic person, so I don't mind being scrunched into a small space. But in the Muppet movie, we would very often find ourselves in a situation where we were out in the real world, like riding in a taxi cab, where there might be three or four of us sort of jammed underneath where the seat would have been in a regular automobile. But since this film was all in a fantasy world, which was designed for us to operate in, we virtually never had that same kind of discomfort. So all of our sets were designed with knowing that we wanted to be able to get underneath the ground or through a rock wall. So all of it was designed with trap doors or areas that could be removed. The design and construction by Henson's group and artist Brian Froud was quite an interesting process also. Brian Froud would do an original sketch, and then we would turn that, we would go to have one of our sculptors then sculpt the figure, and then we would mock it up so that we could manipulate it. And then we would try moving this thing, and these things moved in different ways. We would videotape a test, and then we'd all sit around and look at the test and decide what should be done about it. And then Brian would normally redesign the character, and the whole process would begin again. Jim Hanson's new movie, The Dark Crystal, is quite a remarkable achievement. Go see for yourself.
